unnormalised: AIIMS Delhi reported a spike in Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) cases post-monsoon, with Dr. Kumar mentioning a 25% increase compared to last yr. GBS, a rare neurological disorder, affects the nerves, leading to muscle weakness and, in severe cases, paralysis. Health officials are attributing this rise to possible links with recent viral infections common during the monsoon season.
normalised: A-I-I-M-S Delhi reported a spike in Guillain-Barré Syndrome (G-B-S) cases post-monsoon, with Doctor Kumar mentioning a twenty five percent increase compared to last year. G-B-S, a rare neurological disorder, affects the nerves, leading to muscle weakness and, in severe cases, paralysis. Health officials are attributing this rise to possible links with recent viral infections common during the monsoon season.

unnormalised: Symptoms of GBS often start with tingling sensations in the feet and hands, progressing upwards. Patients experiencing such symptoms are advised to consult a neurologist immediately. Early diagnosis and treatment, including IVIg (intravenous immunoglobulin) therapy, are crucial in managing the condition and preventing long-term complications. The estimated cost of treatment at a private hospital is around Rs. 2 lakhs.
normalised: Symptoms of G-B-S often start with tingling sensations in the feet and hands, progressing upwards. Patients experiencing such symptoms are advised to consult a neurologist immediately. Early diagnosis and treatment, including I-V-I-g (intravenous immunoglobulin) therapy, are crucial in managing the condition and preventing long-term complications. The estimated cost of treatment at a private hospital is around rupee two lakhs.

unnormalised: Neurology departments across major hospitals in Mumbai and Chennai are also seeing a similar trend, although numbers haven't been officially released. Experts are emphasizing the importance of maintaining hygiene and seeking prompt medical attention for any respiratory or gastrointestinal infections. "Prevention is key," stated Dr. Sharma from Apollo Hospitals, Chennai.

unnormalised: Research is ongoing to pinpoint the specific triggers for GBS. While a definitive cause remains elusive, infections like Zika virus and Campylobacter jejuni are suspected culprits. The use of PPE kits is mandated for all staff. Further studies are needed to understand the connection between monsoon-related infections and the increased incidence of GBS.
normalised: Research is ongoing to pinpoint the specific triggers for G-B-S. While a definitive cause remains elusive, infections like Zika virus and Campylobacter jejuni are suspected culprits. The use of P-P-E kits is mandated for all staff. Further studies are needed to understand the connection between monsoon-related infections and the increased incidence of G-B-S.

unnormalised: The health ministry has issued an advisory urging citizens to take precautionary measures such as washing hands frequently, drinking boiled water, and avoiding crowded places. Awareness campaigns are also being planned to educate the public about the symptoms and potential risks of GBS. A helpline number, 104, is available for any queries or assistance.

unnormalised: This sudden increase in GBS cases raises concerns about the public health infrastructure's preparedness. Hospitals are ramping up their capacity to accommodate the expected surge in patients. The availability of ventilators and specialized neurological care units is being closely monitored. A nationwide survey is underway and will be completed by 30/11/2024.
